personalized_feedback:
Dylan — I’ve enjoyed watching your DRIVER transformation this term. You’ve moved from intuitive, ad-hoc answers to consistently decomposing finance problems into clear DRIVER steps: you frame questions, isolate drivers, translate them into quantifiable inputs, and communicate results in business terms. Concretely, your project notes showed a tidy breakdown of revenue drivers and a readable decision logic that a CFO could follow — that kind of systematic thinking is exactly what separates reactive analysts from trusted finance partners.

Next steps to sharpen impact: one area to focus on is financial-concepts accuracy — for example, I noticed a recurring assumption around discounting and terminal value that would benefit from tighter justification. Actionable next steps: explicitly state cost-of-capital assumptions, run a sensitivity on WACC and growth rates, and document why a chosen terminal method (perpetuity vs. exit multiple) fits the business model. On the technical-implementation front, raise the robustness of your models so they’re business-ready: add simple validation checks (e.g., non-negative cash flows where appropriate), build a clear assumptions sheet, and include a scenario tab that maps to stakeholder questions (best/worst/base). These are small, high-leverage changes that reduce decision risk in board-level discussions.

Keep going — your habit of converting fuzzy problems into driver-based components will pay off in any finance role, from FP&A to corporate development. Treat this as a career-long craft: each model you tighten and each assumption you surface compounds into faster, higher-trust decisions. I’m excited to see where your systematic instincts take you next — aim for models that don’t just compute answers, but confidently guide business choices.
